Award.AwardTitle: MRI: Acquisition of a Transient Absorption Spectrometer
Award.AbstractNarration:
With this award from the Major Research Instrumentation (MRI) and Chemistry Research Instrumentation and Facilities (CRIF) programs, Florida State University will acquire a transient absorption spectrometer. Transient absorption (TA) spectroscopy is a powerful technique for monitoring the change of absorbance of light by a sample (i. e., color) with respect to time after excitation by a flash of light. While nanosecond transient absorption technique is not new, its application to unexplored areas of research can yield important results on the photophysical properties of molecules and materials. These results will directly impact applications such as solar energy conversion, photodynamic therapy, photocatalysis, solid-state lighting, and metal ion sensing. The user-friendly nature of the proposed instrument will improve the scholarship, education and training of students at all levels. The TA spectrometer will be open to all academic institutions in the region, including minority-serving institutions, and women?s colleges as well as industrial partners.

The proposal is aimed at enhancing research especially in areas such as (a) studying photophysical properties of molecules and materials; (b) providing insight into electron/energy transfer; (c) investigating excited state quenching; (d) studying photochemical reactions; and (e) investigating excition diffusion and charge separation.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The primary goal of this project was to order and install a nanosecond transient absorption (TA) spectrometer in the Materials Characterization User Facility at Florida State University. TA spectrometers are used to monitor color changes over time after exciting the sample with flash of light. This technique is key to characterizing light driven events in everything from biological photosynthesis to solar cells. Within a year of the award, the laser and spectrometer were purchased, installed and operational for any researcher interested in performing TA. Over the subsequent two years, the spectrometer has been used by over a dozen research groups from six different universities to monitor electron transfer from molecules to semiconductors, excited state lifetimes in inorganic solids/particles, and photocatalysis, just to name a few. These measurements and results are key to first understanding and then increasing the efficiency of these processes for applications including in LEDs, solar cells, display technologies, photodetectors, radioactive waste management, and more. Results obtained on the instrument have been included in more than 20 published/submitted manuscripts and over 50 presentations at conferences/seminars. The spectrometer has also had a significant impact on teaching, training, and student learning with more than two dozen graduate and undergraduate students having hands-on experience with the spectrometer. This group includes under-represented scientists and students at primarily undergraduate institutions via FAMU (a historically black university with >40% from underrepresented minority groups),  the University of North Florida (a primary undergraduate institution), and the FSU summer NSF-REU program. Additionally, in an effort to reach a larger audience, we have generated several videos describing both TA spectroscopy and results of our research that are available to the public via YouTube and the Global Educational Outreach for Science Engineering and Technology (GEOSET).
